trans-unit.source: Overview of rotation
trans-unit.target: Overview of rotation

trans-unit.source: Rotation is the touch-optimized technique used by UWP apps to enable users to turn an object in a circular direction (clockwise or counter-clockwise).
trans-unit.target: Rotation is the touch-optimized technique used by UWP apps to enable users to turn an object in a circular direction (clockwise or counter-clockwise).

trans-unit.source: Depending on the input device, the rotation interaction is performed using:
trans-unit.target: Depending on the input device, the rotation interaction is performed using:

trans-unit.source: A mouse or active pen/stylus to move the rotation gripper of a selected object.
trans-unit.target: A mouse or active pen/stylus to move the rotation gripper of a selected object.

trans-unit.source: Touch or passive pen/stylus to turn the object in the desired direction using the rotate gesture.
trans-unit.target: Touch or passive pen/stylus to turn the object in the desired direction using the rotate gesture.

trans-unit.source: Windows 8 supports three types of rotation: free, constrained, and combined.
trans-unit.target: Windows 8 supports three types of rotation: free, constrained, and combined.

trans-unit.source: Type
trans-unit.target: Type

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: Free rotation
trans-unit.target: Free rotation

trans-unit.source: Free rotation enables a user to rotate content freely anywhere in a 360 degree arc.
trans-unit.target: Free rotation enables a user to rotate content freely anywhere in a 360 degree arc.

trans-unit.source: When the user releases the object, the object remains in the chosen position.
trans-unit.target: When the user releases the object, the object remains in the chosen position.

trans-unit.source: Free rotation is useful for drawing and layout applications such as Microsoft PowerPoint, Word, Visio, and Paint; and Adobe Photoshop, Illustrator, and Flash.
trans-unit.target: Free rotation is useful for drawing and layout applications such as Microsoft PowerPoint, Word, Visio, and Paint; and Adobe Photoshop, Illustrator, and Flash.

trans-unit.source: Constrained rotation
trans-unit.target: Constrained rotation

trans-unit.source: Constrained rotation supports free rotation during the manipulation but enforces snap points at 90 degree increments (0, 90, 180, and 270) upon release.
trans-unit.target: Constrained rotation supports free rotation during the manipulation but enforces snap points at 90 degree increments (0, 90, 180, and 270) upon release.

trans-unit.source: When the user releases the object, the object automatically rotates to the nearest snap point.
trans-unit.target: When the user releases the object, the object automatically rotates to the nearest snap point.

trans-unit.source: Constrained rotation is the most common method of rotation, and it functions in a similar way to scrolling content.
trans-unit.target: Constrained rotation is the most common method of rotation, and it functions in a similar way to scrolling content.

trans-unit.source: Snap points let a user be imprecise and still achieve their goal.
trans-unit.target: Snap points let a user be imprecise and still achieve their goal.

trans-unit.source: Constrained rotation is useful for applications such as web browsers and photo albums.
trans-unit.target: Constrained rotation is useful for applications such as web browsers and photo albums.

trans-unit.source: Combined rotation
trans-unit.target: Combined rotation

trans-unit.source: Combined rotation supports free rotation with zones (similar to rails in [Guidelines for panning](guidelines-for-panning.md)) at each of the 90 degree snap points enforced by constrained rotation.
trans-unit.target: Combined rotation supports free rotation with zones (similar to rails in [Guidelines for panning](guidelines-for-panning.md)) at each of the 90 degree snap points enforced by constrained rotation.

trans-unit.source: If the user releases the object outside of one of 90 degree zones, the object remains in that position; otherwise, the object automatically rotates to a snap point.
trans-unit.target: If the user releases the object outside of one of 90 degree zones, the object remains in that position; otherwise, the object automatically rotates to a snap point.

trans-unit.source: Note A user interface rail is a feature in which an area around a target constrains movement towards some specific value or location to influence its selection.
trans-unit.target: Note A user interface rail is a feature in which an area around a target constrains movement towards some specific value or location to influence its selection.
